[3391187]

There is a separate Q&A thread, however....

To access resources, send a General to the location & select collect resource. Remember that you have to have control of villages in between you & the resource, (or your master/follower).

Yes, you can attack/capture any village with your General.


Check out the Q&A's, nearly 1k post's, so plenty to read through. Plus use the help tab at top of page, loads of info there also.

On october 4, 2012
Launcelot

I'll try for #1 .. if our map gets more players it will be more realistic..


About the advanced strategy for trade, yes it works better. I know what I'm telling you because I invented it. Granted there may be others like me who also figured it out without someone telling them, but I was kind enough to tell my friends all about it and help them with their game. I don't keep secrets because I want to contribute to having skill level increased in the maps that I play. More skill = more challenge = better game.


Again how it works...


1. Run around the map with a general loaded with a large number of troops, take a new village, dump troops in.


2. Take turns, recruit more troops, build stuff.. whetever. Raise trade to a certain value (desired value using calculator), you want the most profit with the least turns.


3. Remove troops, leave just as many as needed to get trade stabilized ('=' sumbol), your general goes to the next village with the rest of his troops, combined with your new recruits.


4. Repeat.


Take note: depending on how much free space you have left to grow, and how far you need to go, some other time you may want to come back to one of those already established villages (=) to work on their trade a bit further, by dumping your troops in there and when you're done, make sure it's again at (=).


If you apply the strategy correctly, you won't believe how much stronger your economy will become compared to the conventional way.

On october 4, 2012
Launcelot

The break point is the one where you get the most profit in the least amount of turns. Also it's not always the same, it depends on village's initial trade and number of troops you dump in. I'll give you an example using a 5-node village and 500 troops.


If you use the trade calculator which many of us have been using because it's very handy, you will come up with the following results:


At turn #8 the village's trade will be 13..
At turn #10 it will be 19..
At turn #12 it will be 24..


How do you choose when to stop, stabilize (=) and move on? With simple math.. in the first case you stop at turn #8 that means it's like you're getting 13/8 = 1.62 trade for every single turn. In the second case it's 19/10 = 1.9 and in the third it's 24/12 = 2 trade for every single turn. Which do you prefer?


If looking at the graph, you see that it gets better you keep on doing it.. when you notice that it starts getting worse, then you take the peak and leave it there. Like I said, you pick the most profit with the least turns taken. That is your break point, and everytime it's different, depending on village's trade and troops dumped in.


So back in our example what you do is this, you take 12 turns, raise trade to 24 and then you leave 12 of those 500 troops in the village, trade stabilizes at 24 trade (=) and you move on with your 488. But meanwhile in those 12 turns, won't you have recruited anything? So your new recruits, join 488 units and with all of them you move on to the next village.


Meanwhile don't forget to have your borders secured etc.., obviously the strategy does not tell you to have 12 troops in every border of yours.. borders are a different story I think that is pretty much self explanatory.
On october 4, 2012
Launcelot

Oh before anyone says anything (someone knows who I'm talking to) yes the calculator does not work exactly like it should, it gets stuck at high values.. but when it does work (for lower values) it works fine, the results are correct, tested and confirmed. At very high values unfortunately it freezes. It's also tough to read between close turns (like for example you want turn #25 and #26 .. yeah, it will probably display #25 and then #35 or something). But at low values it gets a lot better, like in our example in my previous post, it displayed #8, #10 and #12.


Unfortunately the current version has a few problems.. previous worked flawlessly and for ANY value.. even for a million troops. I hope they get it fixed.

Launcelot

No trade no game!


You will need to take turns, you'll go bankrupt, you will lose all those villages with negative trade, starting from the worst and you may also lose a number of troops.. until you've walked out of the situation you're in and then you'll be able to continue conquering. The point at which it happens is not fixed, depends on many factors.. I've seen dumb players with -600 that keep on making it worse and their generals not complaining. Yours apparently rebelled at -300.. I think it's got to do with title as well as reputation.. I can't confirm this but for one all those -600'ers I've seen were all Emperors, and they all had high rep so to me that's an indication.


Taking villages always goes together with trade, you can't just conquer half the map without taking turns! Unless it's an empty map and you're hunting barbarics..

Alright...


You asked for -36 trade with 859 troops... and you wanted the first 100 turns. For starters you don't need the first 100 turns because you will only waste your turns if you keep staying in that village for any longer than 20-25 turns. To give you an example I'm currently dumping roughly 3,500 troops at -49 and -64 villages and about 25 turns is the most I ever take, then I move on to the next. You won't need more. Now, I dunno how you use the graph and I said this version of the calculator is hard to use (until they get it fixed, hopefully like the older version was), but it's not impossible. Here...


turn 1, trade -34
turn 2, trade -31
turn 3, trade -29
turn 4, trade -25
turn 5, trade -22
turn 6, trade -17
turn 7, trade -11
turn 8, trade 7
turn 9, trade 15
turn 10, trade 20
turn 11, trade 24
turn 13, trade 31
turn 15, trade 36
turn 17, trade 40
turn 20, trade 46
turn 23, trade 52


You will stop taking turns at turn 15 because this is where you get 2.4 trade/turn which is the max you'll ever get with 859 troops on a -36 village. Anything less than 15 turns you'll be getting worse, anything more than 15 turns you'll be getting worse. At turn 15 you stop, you leave 18 troops to hold your trade at 36 and you use the rest 841 troops, together with any new recruits (in those 15 turns) to the next village.


Why that strategy pays off the more you grow? Because you reach a point where you recruit more troops then the ones you leave behind in a village to hold your trade stable. For example we said you will leave 18 troops behind right? How many will you be able to recruit in 15 turns? With let's say 8 recruiters? You should be able to line up swords at least 3 times.. and that's with 8 recruiters, imagine what happens with more..


So the more you take villages and raise trade, the more troops you get on your general to dump to the next. And even when you switch from -36 villages to -49 because you ran out of 6-node ones, trade and recruits will still run faster than deficit and that means more trade for you.


I don't waste a single sword on the grid, I have 16 recruiters, and with that strategy I have ended up EARNING 50 gold per turn as we speak. Trade and recruits run THAT much faster than deficit. If age wasn't an issue I would end up taking 20-node villages (at -400) without even killing recruitment. By the way so far I have never killed recruitment like I said earlier I keep recuiting like mad, not a single sword goes wasted.


Sorry for the long post but I dunno how else to explain.

Launcelot
45424Well I'm the best out there in using the conventional way, mainly due to preventing any loss of troops if possible. (e.g. using pure cats to attack villages without MA, using pure ballistas to defend unless there are MA in attack force)

Alright.. since you brought it up, let's see some facts then..


You died 72 years 1 month. How many turns is that.. 72 - 20 (because you start at 20) = 52 x 48 turns (because 1 year = 48 turns) = 2496 + 4 (for the extra month) = 2500 turns.


You have taken 2500 turns and produced 2363 trade. In other words you produced 2363/2500 = 0.945 trade for every turn you took..


Dj is still alive and 66 years 3 months. Using the same math you will find he has taken 2220 turns. He has produced 2343 trade, in other words 1.055 trade for every turn he took, so far.. because he's still alive, his trade keeps improving and in the next 5 years (or 240 turns which is a lot for our strategy believe me), he should increase the ratio a lot further.. of course, if he's still alive. But take note he's 5 years younger and still ahead of you.


Now, let's take a look at someone who's a lot older, which means he has given the strategy time to pay off.. after all I've said before that the older you get, the more it pays off right? Let's take a look at me then..


Here's me.. I'm 110 years 8 months, so we do the math blah blah, I've taken 4352 turns. My trade is 8151 and that's because I just took a village which I'm on my way to raise, in a few minutes you can add another 140 which I'll get in 15 turns. But no problem, let's just say 8151.. How does 1.873 look? I make almost 1 trade more for every single turn, than your conventional way. 1 trade per turn means 48 trade per day (or a year).. or 480 trade per decade. Or nearly 1800 trade per average lifespan more than conventional way.. How does that sound?


I'll say it again, give it time. The more you grow older, grow trade etc., the more it pays off. It's like a muscle car, it's got a great top-end even if it's heavy and may fall behind for the first few seconds of the race.. but soon it'll be gone and you'll see its tail lights at the finish line.

[4978382]

Hey, Im new here.
What more than one worker do?
If i have 1 he can build buildings and cost of this buildings is fixed. So what more builders do?
On october 10, 2012
Launcelot

^ With more workers you build faster.. you will notice that by lining up a set of hammers, more workers will progress building further The construction has progressed to 2.. 3.. 4.. etc..


Also there is a building called construction site when you have that, your workers will produce small quantities of food and gold when you're not building anything, and the more workers you have, the more they produce.. helps at hard times but I'm afraid you won't notice any major benefits until you've really progressed into your game because you need a high level of that building and a lot of workers to make it worthwhile..


As for buildings' cost, that is fixed for each level.. but the higher the level the more they cost. Also for war machines (catapults and ballistas), their cost is not fixed either, it's directly affected by your workshop's level but here it works the other way around, the better workshop you have, the cheaper they get.
On october 10, 2012
[4978382]

So you want to say that they build by their own and if I set 3 hammers in row on puzzle and gain 1+ hammer it only help build faster and hammers from puzzle is not only way to build objects?
And if I have more workers it just reduce number of hammers (1hammer= 0,5h?) needed to finish building?
On october 10, 2012
Launcelot

That's right the more workers you have the less hammers are needed to complete construction and therefore less turns. Hammer is the only icon that involves building. For example if it requires 12 sets of hammers, if it progresses by 1 everytime you will need 12.. but if it progresses by 2 you will need 6.. if it progresses by 3 you will need 4.. etc. Adding extra workers does just that, improves progress and reduces turns needed to complete construction.

[4978382]

I don't think this is the case. Once you start a revolt, you're free to attack your master. Two things would come into play here.


1) If you become someone's master and you have a battle with them going on elsewhere, their general will flee from the battle.
2) If you or anyone else takes your master's capital, all the troops your master had in a follower's capital disappear. I don't know if this holds for barbaric villages or not; but in a followers capital, the former masters troops are gone.


So, no, you don't have to have enough troops to actually win the revolt, just start one and be able to take their capital before the battle at your capital finishes.

On october 25, 2012
Launcelot

Poison appears when your health turns bad, at "home" screen right next to potion and it's not such a waste as you may think. Depends how you use it. If you use it early on because you suddenly don't like your spot and you wanna start over somewhere else, that's a waste.. you better off wait it out, sooner or later you'll collapse, no reason to spend your tokens.


But poison can be very useful if you've progressed far into the game, your health has gone bad and you've got a bunch of followers that give you a lot of prestige. If they die before you do, you'll lose it, and that will likely have a huge impact on your final score. So there are cases when 30 tokens can be just what you need, end your game (or should I say "escape from your game") with your prestige intact, enter the pantheon with a nice score.


Of course if you couldn't care less about scores and pantheon, forget all about poisons.. and potions as a matter of fact.
On october 25, 2012
Launcelot

^ I forgot to mention, before you use poison, make sure you've noticed which of your followers are in bad health. If it's your bigger ones, then you may want to consider using it. If your bigger ones are still good and only your smaller followers are about to kick it, then maybe you shouldn't worry about it just yet. It's really about your plans and how you wanna proceed. I'm just showing you how poison *should* be used.

On november 11, 2012
Launcelot

The table with the units has a few errors, like for instance an attacking catapult isn't left with 44 hp after killing a soldier, because since its full health is 60 hp that means it loses 16 hp for every soldier and that means a catapult can only kill 3. This is false, a catapult kills 4 and in fact they do a 50% damage to the 5th. Same with ballistas when they defend against soldiers. So where you see 44 hp, make that roughly 47, which means they lose 13 hp for every soldier not 16.. and 13 hp x 4 soldiers = 52 hp, out of 60 initial, machine is left with 8 hp to injure the 5th soldier.


Similarly machines vs knights, where you see 26 hp left, make that 34, because the machine kills 2 knights it doesn't kill just 1.. and injures the 3rd.


And last, machines vs pikemen, archers, cavaliers and mounted knights, generally all those units with 70 hp, where you see 36 hp left for the machine make that 42 because they kill 3 of each of those not just 2, and they injure the 4th.


Generally catapults and ballistas have been a little underrated by a few points in that table, but a few points for every duel they fight that makes a lot of points in the end.. basically in that table it's like they got 150% bonus instead of 200%.


For all the above I can show you screenshots.

Launcelot

http://support.motion-twin.com/site/44 this is the main support, I would click on "account problems" even if it says it's not intended for bug reports, for one because everything else is entirely irrelevant and two, since it's something that is destroying your game, it stops being a bug report anymore and escalates into a problem that needs urgent attention. If you want to submit a screenshot, I recommend you either click on the barbaric and mouse over your general, or click on the general and mouse over the barbaric.. either way, you'll have both the barbaric and the general shown in one screenshot. Circle the area that needs attention as well if you want.


If anyone thinks there's a better place to submit things like that please do tell.. but remember it's different to just report a random bug you discovered, which can be dealt with in months, and entirely different to require urgent attention because that little sh.. err thing is screwing your game right now..

On december 1, 2012
Launcelot

It's not random, it depends on a good number of factors, mainly being the number of troops you have in his capital against the number of troops he's got at his capital. If your number is much greater than his for example you have 100 and he's got 30 or 50, no chance. If he still has less than yours but close, for example he has 70 or 80 then he may get it started. Another factor is your overall strength against his, for example your trade and army size in your entire kingdom against his, the bigger the gap the more likely to fail. Again, absolutely not random.
On december 1, 2012
dabster

I would compromise and say its both random and dependant on factors that arent set in stone.

I have had revolts start where the follower had no chance, likewise we all know that sometimes you get the 'your troops are scared', even when master has no troops at all in said capital.

A good master would allow you to have your own followers. A good idea for masters is to establish friendly relations with their more competent followers having a skilled follower is crucial to gaining the higher tier titles.


A good master would allow their better vassals to have followers of their own as that would offset their loss to taxes. Just look at Carl, for instance. In this highest ranking game he had an emperor as a follower. By allowing that emperor to have followers of his or her own, he was able to keep that follower loyal.

On december 15, 2012
Launcelot

Village is self-trading no matter what, if there's enough troops it will keep rising whether it's connected to your capital or not. If it's not connected, you keep paying those troops but you're not earning profit (positive trade). If the village is on deficit (negative trade), you're paying for the village too.


SpiritWolfe no problem.. nothing you can do but laugh it off..

On december 19, 2012
Launcelot
Empi3what does it mean "You cannot revolt so soon after revolting."
How often can one revolt?

Once every 24 hours, successfully or not. Whether you fail to start a revolt because your troops are "scared", or you succeed to start but you lose the battle, or you succeed both to start and win the battle but you get conquered once again.. it's always 24 hours till next attempt.


LexicusReally important question:
Can i dismiss a region? I've conquored something and now i dont want it... can i ... leave it, so it becomes savage?

Only if you go bankrupt, in which case you will lose villages starting with the ones with the highest cost. Also if you get conquered, you'll lose everything at once and then you can decide which villages to take back. But I assume neither option really interests you, best find somebody you can donate to, preferably a neighbor.

On january 8, 2013
[1181613]

What happens if you don't spend turns but you are still active?
I have 100 turns on grid and when I point with my mouse over it shows turns wasted 43/87. What those numbers mean?
On january 8, 2013
dabster
grinicWhat happens if you don't spend turns but you are still active?
I have 100 turns on grid and when I point with my mouse over it shows turns wasted 43/87. What those numbers mean?

They tick like normal turns, one every 30 minutes.
When it reaches 87/87, REAL turns will start to happen: troops cost gold/trade happens and population eats food. Everything like when you take a turn yourself, but without gaining anything.


This happens until your food has run out, now citizens start to die, when the last dies YOU die and life starts over.
With gold, when it runs out your troops starts to disappear until you have no left (except on generals reputation and in capital with barracks), when all troops are gone you start to lose villages.


edit; if you take a turn now, it will be 99 turns left and still 43/87 (or what it says by now). Once a wasted turn has been used it can never come back.
You get more wasted (the high number), when your age goes up.

dabster

distance times distance equal negative trade


1 step away is 1*1= -1
2 steps is 2*2= -4
3 steps is 3*3= -9
6 steps, 6*6= -36

And so on

why do you have to buy poison?
On february 18, 2013
Launcelot

a. You're bored to death and don't wanna have to wait a few days until you collapse. Silly way to waste your tokens imo.


b. You don't intend to take any more potions because they cost too much, you're in bad health and in the meantime you've got yourself a very respectable prestige that you don't wanna put at stake (with followers dieing/revolting). Sometimes the game can seriously troll you, making you linger in bad health almost forever, and just about when a bunch of followers die and your precious prestige goes out the window suddenly you're 6 feet under. This can seriously damage your final score when you enter the pantheon, so if a good score is what you're after, poison can be your way out. This is the only good reason to spend tokens on poisons.

[895339]

Might be a silly question but:
I presume Wall affects not just the capital, but all other territories, allowing you to essentially 'barricade' a chokepoint with loads of troops that someone has to beat down unless I have given them passage rights?
On february 18, 2013
Launcelot
Boudicahow long does bad health last?
minimum?
maximum?
average?

I have personally seen it last from 1 single turn, to more than 50 years.


RaPlMight be a silly question but:
I presume Wall affects not just the capital, but all other territories, allowing you to essentially 'barricade' a chokepoint with loads of troops that someone has to beat down unless I have given them passage rights?

Wall reduces the number of duels when a battle is underway making it last longer, so that you get more time to organize your defense, bring reinforcements, etc. This affects only the capital. It also blocks passage, so that anyone who wants to pass through any of your villages with troops in it (no troops = automatic right of passage, wall or not), need to have your permission or fight you in battle.

On april 17, 2013
EliteDelta

How do I get knights? I'm a baron and I have a level 2 military academy but how do i get them? O.o
On april 17, 2013
harryb93

You need metal which is one of the three rare resources that appear randomly on the map and once depleted at a location they spawn somewhere else. Your Military Academy just reduces the cost of metal needed for a knight and for other soldiers.


Looking at your map, Alvinorley has metal and to get it just send your general to the location and click collect resources.


Also on a side note, knights aren't that amazing. Look toward something like pike-men instead.
On april 17, 2013
Launcelot

Military Academy is used to make Mounted Knights and Mounted Archers, who require metal/horses and cotton/horses respectively. Starting cost 6, then -1 for each upgrade all the way down to 2.


Knights are made with Guard Tower, a very expensive building, for a very expensive unit. What harry said is true, if you put down what they cost and what they offer in battle, Pikemen are more cost effective. They cost half the resources for every level, when they have more than half of a Knight's health (70% to be exact).


However, Knights are still the better unit, they beat more enemies (they lose only to 1 of 2 war machines depending which one is on attack/defense, and Archers.. that makes them 2 units they lose to.. when Pikemen lose to 4, Knights included).


If you ask me, I prefer Knights, for two simple reasons; in almost all cases, if you pair them up with Mounted Archers and war machines, you get the most solid force in the game, as they ideally cover each other's weakness. The other reason is purely aesthetic.. Knights are classy and you don't get to see as often. Of course this is just my opinion, cause at the end of the day the only thing that matters is to win, no matter how.

On april 21, 2013
LongrangeDA

Question: should I mount my units? I got tons of horses, but nobody close got archers, so does the mounting give a small bonus against normal soldiers, cats and ballistas?
On april 21, 2013
Launcelot

Mounted units are generally stronger than their likes on foot, except Mounted Knights. Cavaliers are stronger than soldiers and Mounted Archers are stronger than Archers. But Knights are stronger than Mounted Knights, who are great only against soldiers. Knights will beat almost every opponent but they cost a lot to make.


If soldiers is what you're after, make Mounted Knights. For cats/ballistas you need Mounted Archers. And don't make Cavaliers, unless horses is the only thing you have and you're in a difficult situation. Otherwise wait for metal/cotton and make other mounted units.


By definition, the strongest units in the game:


Cat/Ballista (because of their immense bonus - they lose only to MA)
Mounted Archer (because they cancel bonuses - they lose only to Knight)
Knight (because of their massive stamina - they lose to Archer & Cat/Bal)
Mounted Knight (because of their bonus against the most common unit)


Normally, I don't include Mounted Knights in my elite squad for the simple fact that you can do without them if you have war machines. But MA are irreplaceable for neutralizing bonuses and beating war machines, Knights too for beating MA. However if you're low on war machines and/or unable to mass produce, Mounted Knights can be very useful.

On april 21, 2013
phoenixxx

Imagine 200 wood for 1 knight, which is one every turn if you have 20 lumberjacks.how does this work? wood for knights?
On april 21, 2013
Launcelot

You convert wood to metal if you have cauldron, so for every X amount of wood you can get X amount of metal which you use to create Pikemen and Knights. Metal is the only resource in the game that you can create on your own, without having to find it in the map. Lumberjacks produce wood, so the more of those you have, the more wood you make. Likewise, the better cauldron you have, the more metal you create with a given amount of wood. That is how you use wood for Knights.


And 45424 is right, Knights are best to be made only when cauldron is significantly upgraded, but I'd say level 4 is enough at least in my book. Then you need a good number of Lumberjacks and eventually Knights won't be too much of a budget.


I use MA for defense too, on attack I want speed so war machines is the only option. If an intimidating force of MA's is guarding the village I try to work my way through another path, if that's not possible I'll think twice before attacking. I'll be ready for reinforcements and prepared that the battle may last a very long time (depending on the enemy), and have a backup plan in case it turns ugly. All things considered, it's not a very good idea to stall your own attack, but for defense MA's own.


Real battles are against level 4 players btw. Below that it's usually training, unless said player is like 60 years old and his capital has a bridge (aka is able to produce a serious army), in that case even level 3 can be tough to take down. In my last map I beat a Duke that was able to produce triple numbers in a day, I was a Prince back then. It was fun.


As for the rest.. to each their own. But facts remain.

On may 3, 2013
LongrangeDA

Question 1. If I revolt, will I be the defender or the attacker?
Question 2. If I attack a General at my land, will I be the defender or the attacker?
On may 3, 2013
Launcelot

Defender in both cases. Although it may seem like you're the attacker because in both cases you are the one that initiates the battle, what actually happens is:


1. You start a rebellion trying to take back control of your town, so you want to push the enemy out of the gates while the enemy tries to get back in. That puts you in defensive position even if you've started the battle.
2. This is a simple "get off my lawn" case. Your general approaches demanding that the enemy leaves right away. The enemy refuses and attacks. Only thing that differs from real case scenarios is that the enemy has no option to comply with your demand or not, so once you've provoked the battle is underway. So again this puts you in defensive position even if you're the one that got to the location with the demand.

On may 27, 2013
Launcelot
whitenoise

how is the score for the pantheon calculated?

and is it different for the beginner and other maps?

On the pantheon page hover over view all these stats you see there are taken into account. The larger the better except age. Prestige at death is more important than personal best and points are spread equally between army and trade while reputation is the least important of all. Normal difficulty maps score much more points than beginner maps, my guess is that there's a multiplier set for each difficulty that decides the final score, but I don't know what it is. I didn't bother to go any deeper than this, but you may be able to look into the point system in more detail if you study the table, like compare player stats, especially those that look similar in certain areas and different in others.

HenryIV

Q1: Let's suppose I got 3 pieces of land and the title of "Sir". If I lose one of my villages to another player, does my title drop back to "Master"? What happens to my Level 2 buildings in this case?You keep your title and can still build level 2 buildings

Q2: If a battle is imminent, is there any reconnaissance mission I can do before my troops get annihilated?not really, other than hovering over the location or general and looking to see each type of troops there and if ? or ?? or ???

Q3: If I manage to conquer another player's capital, can I see how many troops he have on each of his conquered territories?yes but only after he reconquers them - your taking of his capital will mean he loses all his territory and all his troops at other villages become savage troops

Q4: Is it possible to choose in a battle which enemy unit to combat, or choosing one of mines to go first? (A knight instead of a soldier, for example.)no - totally random - equip your generals carefully before engaging

MagicDragon

If you have enough lumberjacks and a level five cauldron (I think that's the one), you can make three units of iron and still have wood left over. I think at level 5, its 50 units of wood to produce one nugget of iron. With a level 5 cabin, you can make 160 units of wood with 16 lumberjacks.


You can make 3 nuggets of iron for each turn of wood production and still have some wood left over.

Launcelot

All injured units fully recover. On a side note, you need to work on your trade before you start worrying about your garrison. You can't dump at his capital whatever you produce because you'll go bankrupt and lose your units. Need to stop expanding for a while and reinforce your villages to improve trade and make more money, also need to increase population which is the very heart of your kingdom and all that combined will increase your strength, then you can safely reinforce your garrison at his capital and stop the rebellions. If you keep doing what you're doing they will keep coming one after another.

On july 17, 2013
Launcelot
akilisthow can i make my trade go up rapidly? if i add lot of army to a territory does the trade grow rapidly? or the speed cant be better?

It depends on the amount of troops of course, but also on the village's initial trade (before you dump your troops). The closer to zero, the faster it goes up. For example say you have a village located 4 spaces away, where initial trade is -16 (initial trade is always the square of distance like 2x2, 3x3 etc). So you dump your troops, the more the merrier, start taking turns and watch trade increase. As it starts to approach zero, you will notice that it gets a short boost. The amount of boost and how long it lasts also depends on the number of troops. Eventually village will get into positive trade and as it walks away from zero you will notice the boost gradually fades, until trade will kind of struggle to increase any further. At that point it's asking for more troops and it's your call to do it or move along into another.


So, a very distant village will have a very negative initial trade, which means it will take a much longer time until it gets its boost, because like we said, boost comes when trade is close to zero. And more or less that's how trade works.
On july 17, 2013
Launcelot
WyrmieI found something weird in my new kingdom.
From my capital, there is a node with two separate paths leading to it, both with four segments... it creates something like an irregular octagon. One path is goes through my kingdom and the other path goes through savage lands.
Annoyingly, my generals all would rather take the savage path, doubling travel speed . I end up having to move my generals halfway through the faster path and send new move orders as they go along. It's rather tedious.
Is this a bug?

I dunno if it's a bug or made intentionally but routes are based on distance, not time. So your general will always take the shortest route, not necessarily the fastest.
On july 17, 2013
45424

This game uses simple shortest path algorithm, which counts your accessible territory AND all savage territory (including barbarian ones) as accessible nodes. Distance is regarded as constant between nodes, regardless of the actual travel time.

[7392589]

Try this site to see how fast your trade will rise. I also noticed (I could be wrong) that trade increases a bit slower if it is further away from your capital. The most important fact is, that when you put a lot of troops in a village, trade will increase much more rapidly.
Your trade building (market) only increases the amount of gold produced by your traders. It doesn't increase your trade faster.


If you are really interested in how to max out your trade and how to maximize your profits, I suggest that you should check out this forum. I won't spoil anything, but if you are willing to spend a little time reading the forum you will discover a lot by yourself. Lots of top players already explained some of their strategies (although not with exact words and detail) but it gives you a good understanding of the game.
I'm also no expert, but by reading the forums and spending some time, I could say that I became a decent player with decent skills. I won't last very long agains the top players, but I'll give them my best and maybe give them a little challenge or maybe a little headache. Just play and see where you come. Every failure gives you an opportunity to learn, but it's up to you if you take it or not.


As John Dewey would say: We do not learn from experience...we learn from reflecting on experience.

On august 8, 2013
Launcelot

What Wyrmie said, distance does affect the amount of turns required to get trade to 0 but only because the farther from 0 you are, the slower it moves. -64 moves slower to get up to -10 than -25 does, so -25 requires less turns, just like if you are into positive trade, the higher it gets the more it struggles to increase further. It's closer to 0 that you get the best value per turn, but one note here; the more troops you have in the village, the more effective your turns become, not only close to 0 but even farther from it. So for example with X troops your effective range may be -10 to +10, but with 3X it can be -20 to +20 and so on. Within that range, you get trade move faster.
On august 8, 2013
MagicDragon

What Launcelot said. I had a village I recently took that started at -100 trade. It took only 41 turns to cancel out the negative trade.

[7392589]

Another extra note: When you let your troops raise trade, trade will stop growing at the point when it reaches your number of soldiers * 2 minus 1.
However, when you remove troops trade will decrease until it reaches a value of your number of soldiers * 2.
This means that you can achieve +1 trade per village with the same amount of troops.

On august 12, 2013
Launcelot

Yeah citizen icons are an exception. The only way to produce more than 1 citizen in a single turn is through combos. I'm sure you have made combos before so you know how that works. A combo that includes 2 sets of citizen icons will produce 2 citizens in a single turn. But you're still not gaining anything, except save yourself a turn, you're still gonna need the same amount of icons per citizen, unlike other types where you can line up another extra icon on the same set and get more stuff.

MagicDragon

I would suggest not going for stability. I have a general with over a 1,000 units and I have him going around raising trade. The thing is, at the same time, I am also recruiting. That way, when he is done at a village, I can remove most of my units, but leave enough so that trade at that village continues to rise (albeit at a slower rate).


Now here is the thing about that trick. You have to constantly add troops to the trade raising general. As the army size rises, the ability to build up trade increases. If you get it large enough (around the size I have it), you can earn more than one gold in trade per turn, but that only works at lower amounts. Additionally, having large numbers of troops allows you to intimidate other players as well as quickly make distant villages trade earning quickly.

Man, I just landed a 5-chain combo on the production grid then immediately died, talk about buzzkill. Anyway, to help answer my own question about trade I'd been taking some data points about the rate of increase.


Growing trade based on army size at 1+ trade per turn
how to read:
e.g. 112t - 117t, 12->13 "if you have from 112 to 117 troops at a village, it will take one turn to increase trade from 12 to 13, and more than one turn for every increase beyond that

69t, 7->8
71t, 8->9
77t, 8->9
112t - 117t, 12->13
118t, 13->14
124t - 125t, 15->16
129t, 16->17
184t, 19->20
191t, 22->23
202t - 207t, 23->24
226t, 24->25
228t, 24->25
234t, 24->25
235t, 25->26
249t, 26->27
255t, 28->29,
309t, 31->32
326t - 327t, 34->35
378t, 41->42


Since the rate of trade increase is doubled after these points (from 1 to 2+ turns to increase trade by 1) they seem like a good place to stop growing trade, based on the size of your army. If there are any errors, it's probably because I combo'd some extra turns and thought that trade stopped growing


Anyway, probably not starting another game since the most efficient play involves logging on at weird time intervals to order generals around. So I hope this is useful to someone.

On august 20, 2013
MagicDragon

On the subject of raising trade, here's a tidbit of information. I've been taking various screenshots of my kingdom as I enter my endgame and I found something interesting. At the age of 120 and one month, my trade was at 4,708. My current age is 122 years and 7 months (my second longest life span). My trade is currently at 5,024. That is an increase of trade by 316 gold.


I think I heard somewhere that a year equals roughly 50 turns. As such, I have aged 2 and a half years since I took that screenshot. That should roughly equate to 125 turns or so. If that number is right, then I've raised my trade by about 2.5 gold per turn. That's a pretty damn good clip.


Here's another data point you might be interested. Shortly after I became emperor this game, I took screenshots of my kingdom. In that first screenshot, I was 98 years and four months old. My trade at that point was at 2,693. My trade since that point has grown by 2,331 gold. In less than 25 I've raised nearly as much trade I did in the first 78. That is the power behind using large armies to build trade.


The real kicker is that I've probably acquired maybe, ten to fifteen additional trade producing villages in the interim. Most of that increase came from raising trade in established villages. What does this mean for you, the player? You should begin building a trade building army as soon as you can. The more you raise trade, the larger the army you can raise.


The larger the army, the easier it is to take distant villages. In fact, my trade building army can take an eleven node village and bring it to zero trade from -121 in forty turns. As it grows, that number of turns will decrease. It I weren't in my endgame, I would taking that village to raise my trade further.


Launce, who is a master of this technique, would probably be twice as high in trade if he had spawned in my spot instead.

Well MD maybe, maybe not.. luck comes into play as well. In my high score map if it wasn't for that huge battle I've told you before, I would have probably raised another thousand troops and trade. On september 21, 2013
Launcelot

pedped Sometimes you want to clear a village as fast as possible before the enemy brings reinforcements, so time can be as important as winning the battle. That usually happens when you're on attack. Other times you may want to delay a battle to keep the enemy busy, which is called distraction. Units that carry large bonuses will attempt to kill the enemy faster, so you want to do it quickly get catapults. On the other hand mounted archers are perfect for making battles take forever because they cancel enemy's bonuses and they have large health.


By the way, that is the only reason mounted archers are very intimidating. Not because they're invincible or anything, I mean slap 100 soldiers against 50 mounted archers and you're gonna win, you'll be left with 20 but it's guaranteed victory. They're intimidating because by the time you've killed them all, the enemy will have enough time to have lunch, take a walk, go fishing and bring a pack of ballistas before they pay your soldiers a quick visit. So you're looking to attack a village guarded by mounted archers, beware.
On september 22, 2013
NERON

pedped[...] knights are those created in the Guard Tower right? and they're label as Paladin? or Paladin and Knight are two different things? They're the same. It's a french translation screw up. At any rate, you shouldn't need them unless you have a excess of those resources.

LauncelotSometimes you want to clear a village as fast as possible[...]In laymen's terms [and to address the question more directly], we use catapults because they attack with 2x speed. Everything else, including MAs, attack in 1x speed. MAs will cancel out the 2x speeds from catapults attacking and ballistae defending thus drawing out the battle.


Faster offence means less time for your opponent to respond and you can get back to upping trade sooner. This may not seem like a big deal early on but when the army sizes scale up, battles can drag on for days [because the number of individual fights doesn't scale with it ].

LauncelotBy the way, that is the only reason mounted archers [...]You shouldn't need to worry about using MAs like this unless your opponent knows what their doing [read: uses catapults] or grow a sizable kingdom and become a target. Most small players don't even use catapults as their main offensive force.

Buying extra turns increase the age of death?
This extra turns decrease my heath?
Exemplo: If I buy 50 extra turns my "age of death" increase?


sorry my english
On october 3, 2013
Launcelot

No, you just age faster because you take more turns, so if you were gonna die in 5 years, or 5 days real time without buying extra turns (remember you get 48 free turns a day, which is roughly a year game time), if you bought once, you would die in 4 days, but game time would still be the same, 5 years.


About extra turns affecting health, allow me to just share my experience because I don't have a definite answer. There was one time I bought a lot of extra turns and my health went bad before I could blink, took a pot and couple years later turned bad again. That went on and on until I figured it wasn't worth it, but that made me think that buying extra turns could have potentially affected my health. Next map it got worse, took 7-8 pots and died in my 70's so I didn't know what to think, all I knew was all hell broke loose ever since I bought these turns on the previous map and it was still haunting me.. and for all I knew it could've been permanent. I even thought about staying away from the game for a while. So I died again and surprisingly, next map went smooth as butter, I don't think I bought more than 2 pots until my 80's and even after 100 it took quite a few days before I had to take another. Long story short, no in my experience it's very unlikely that buying extra turns has any impact on your health at all, so if you see anything strange it has to be coincidence.

On october 14, 2013
NERON

How did you know I didn't have my morning coffee yet?


You can only 'provoke' if you're on your own land. If you were on hostile territory, the option would be 'attack' and you'd have to go through the troops stationed at the village and make the and yours before you can provoke the general unless he's defending.


Anyways, general rule of thumb [pun intended]:
If you're on your own land, you're defending. This includes vassal's lands.
If you're on not on your land, you're attacking. This includes capitals of rebelling followers and savage lands.
If you go to foreign land that's already under attack, you have the option to join the side of your choice by clicking 'view battle'.


Troops following generals don't effect trade. Try your best to avoid taking turns during major battles. I like to use all my turns before embarking on any campaigns and let the turns accumulate a bit during.

[7851397]

Nope Cube.

How do titles work exactly?
I know the "prestige" progression is master-sir-earl-viscout-marquis[...]
but there is also the "war" progression that is baron-?-duke-??-??
How do the "war" titles affect the game? As in, are there buildings unlocks, special bonuses etc unlocked by those titles?
On november 13, 2013
NERON

All titles are based on your prestige. War has nothing to do with it [well unless you gain prestige through war I suppose]. You need to have a title equal to or greater than the one you need to upgrade your palace to a specific level. The level of your palace is the maximum level your other buildings can be upgraded to. Here's a chart:Knight= 1 prestige [Palace lvl1]
Lord= 3 prestige [Palace lvl2]
Baron= 7 prestige
Viscount= 10 prestige [Palace lvl3]
Count= 15 prestige
Marquis= 20 prestige [Palace lvl4]
Duke= 30 prestige
Prince= 50 prestige [Palace lvl5]
King= 75 prestige
Emperor= 100 prestige

Launcelot

Build a wall if you haven't done so already, level 1 will do. No wall means anyone can march onto your kingdom and pass through your villages without passage rights. See if your economy is strong enough to proceed to one of the villages 2 squares away. I would go for the village to the north so that after a while I can get my hands on that metal, it's not much but it's something. If you're not ready, it means that either you're in excess of troops and you need to stop recruiting for a while or you're constructing buildings that require gold. If that's the case, try putting more troops on your lower trade villages and stop recruiting if you must, and complete your constructions so that you can move on. Villages 2 squares away require 4 gold up front (they start from -4), but if your economy is ready to take the hit, with a good number of troops you can probably start gaining after 3 to 5 turns. So taking a new village isn't necessarily a bad thing even if you're struggling to cope with costs. As long as you can survive the initial hit, the added trade can save your ass. The reason it works like that is that trade increases much faster the closer it is to 0. So once it goes from -4 to 0, you'll notice a jump (which depends on the number of troops as well) that will start fading the higher it goes. I bet you're struggling to increase trade right now.

On december 6, 2013
Launcelot

Another thing to consider is increasing your citizens. Looking at your capital, it seems you have 16 to 17 citizens. That is just above the threshold of level 1 granary. This is how it works... When you build your first granary, max food you can store gets a boost from 100 (initial) to 250. In order to get citizen icons often, you need to have more food stored than the square of population. Or if you want to look at it from the opposite side, your citizens need to be less than the square root of stored food. What that means is that level 1 granary can be great up to approx. 15 citizens, because 16 x 16 = 256 and you can't have more than 250 food in level 1. You will still get citizen icons from time to time, just a lot less often.


I can't tell if your granary is level 2 already, maybe it is and you just need more time, but if it isn't, see how you can benefit from level 2... Here you can store up to 600 food, and once you do that, you'll be able to get a horde of citizens up to approx. 25...


So, check that your palace is level 2, if it isn't see how you can start building it (gather resources), so you can start working on level 2 constructions later. And last, keep in mind granary is best paired with farm, because better farm gets you more food per turn. And don't neglect to hire peasants, you need them to keep your granary full.


Wish I could say that's all, I'm afraid there's a lot more to it but this should be enough to get you started.. good luck.

Launcelot
AndreSo if one of my vassals would have his own vassals connecting our 2 kingdoms would that count as us being connected and then him paying me taxes?

He will not pay you taxes unless your kingdoms are connected through his follower's capital. Capitals that your followers conquer belong to you, just as they belong to your followers, but you don't own anything beyond that. So if your kingdoms are only connected through normal villages, then your follower won't pay you taxes.


AndreIf i have access to someones resources and his vassal has resources will i be able to collect from those resources or do i need access to his vassal too?

You need access. You can only collect from your own followers (without needing access that is).


AndreI hear all this talk about giving the vassals lands and dividing the lands upon bad health, how do i do this? Or is there something im missing and also why do the people i attack lose all their land upon vassalisation?

It doesn't mean anything, I dunno who does that. The only thing you'll accomplish by giving villages away just before you die, is ruining your final score. It's like bards and minstrels that write poems and sing songs about you, game just likes to be romantic.


That's how it works when you conquer another capital, player loses his kingdom and has to start over. Although they don't really start over in that they get to keep their capitals (population, buildings etc.), plus they may lose their villages but any troops they had in these villages are still there. Player just needs to go get them back, along with the villages.

On january 16, 2014
Sid96

Does the distance away from your capital affect the rate of trade increase? For example, lets say that I have 50 soldiers in a land 1 unit away from me which has 0 trade, and 50 soldiers in a land 10 units away from me which has 0 trade. Will the closer one get to 10 trade first? Or will the trade increase be the same regardless of distance?
On january 16, 2014
Launcelot
Sid96Does the distance away from your capital affect the rate of trade increase? For example, lets say that I have 50 soldiers in a land 1 unit away from me which has 0 trade, and 50 soldiers in a land 10 units away from me which has 0 trade. Will the closer one get to 10 trade first? Or will the trade increase be the same regardless of distance?

No the rate is not affected. The only reason why closer villages increase their trade faster is because their initial trade is closer to 0 and the closer it is to 0, the faster the increase. So looking to get into positive trade, -25 will take more turns than -9 because it's farther from 0 but other than that, the rate itself is not affected. When -25 eventually becomes -9 it will need the same amount of turns to turn positive like if it was -9 from the beginning, of course given that the number of troops remains the same in both cases. So in your example, trade increase will be exactly the same.

How do you guys go about getting reputation for your Generals? Do you normally use only 1 general for fighting and farm rep on him, or do you spread the rep among all your generals, using a different one per fight?
On january 25, 2014
Launcelot

Spreading it is actually far more efficient. It works sort of like trade, the higher it gets the more it struggles to improve. So if you use only one general he's going to struggle way faster than spreading it among all your generals. And it's safer that way too in case you lose any.

On march 8, 2014
NERON

Trade change is dependent on two values: number of units stationed and the current trade value.


The more troops, the faster the increase unless the number of troops is less than or equal to half of income of the village, in which case, trade will decline or stabilize respectively.


The closer the trade value is to zero, the faster it increases. This goes for negative trade values as well.ex -81 will grow much slower than -25 with the same amount of troops;
-25 and +25 will take the same amount of time to increase by one.

Word of warning though, the farther the node is from your capital, the lower the initial trade deficit.
initial trade= -[# of nodes away^2]
ex:
node right next to your capital starts with = -[1^2]= -1;
4 nodes away = -[4^2]= -16When all else fails, you could always simply wait for your neighbors to die of old age. You can spy on their health on their profiles

[1820396]

Well, I don't know why OTHER people do Paladins, but I see it this way:

a) Paladin doesn't cost the same as two Pikemen. For two Pikemen you need two soldiers. For one Paladin you need just one soldier.

b) when you have two Pikemen and get into the fight where one of them gets 70 damage, he dies. In the next battle you have just one Pikeman. If the same happens with one Paladin (for same cost in resources as those two Pikemen), after the battle you have one perfectly healthy Paladin again.
On april 2, 2014
Launcelot
AndreI really dont understand this: Paladins have 100 HP, Pikes have 70, and cost half as much as Paladins, so for every Paladin you make you could instead get 140HP that also has bonuses against 2 troops. So why are people making Paladins?

I don't disagree with the way you put it, but there is another way to look at it. Knights (Paladins) are in fact the 3rd strongest unit in the game, losing only to archers and either one of catapults or ballistas. The strongest units are without a doubt catapults and ballistas because not only they have their bonus against almost everyone but they lose only to mounted archers, who in turn lose only to Knights but they have no bonus. So if you look at it based on unit vs unit, Knights come 3rd as they lose only to 2 units. Pikemen on the other hand lose to 4: either one of catapults or ballistas, mounted archers, archers and knights.


So it's not as simple as 1+1=2 although, like I said, what you said is true, it does seem like a waste of metal but strategically, it isn't. If you want to fight cavalry (minus mounted archers), then it's Pikemen all the way, but Knights are much better all-around. Then again, staregy is something so personal that you can't really say who's right and who's wrong. I don't like Pikemen, tried them a few times, didn't work for me. So what I do is keep my metal and wait for horses and make mounted knights, I find these much more useful than Pikemen. Once I'm level 4 with cauldron I start making knights. Works for me so I stick with it.

AndreHow fast can you kill 8 soldiers with Catapults?

Depends on the number of catapults and on the area of the battle. If you have 10+ cats and the battle takes place in a regular village, it will be approx. 40 minutes. If you have less cats - an hour. If it's a capital with a wall, it depends on the wall level (number of combats taking place at the same time). Basically 1 cat kills a soldier in 18-22 minutes.

On april 11, 2014
blue4029

what are the titles in order? master,sir,etc. also what do I do if the closest undefended village is 8 hours away?
On april 11, 2014
Astralenigma

Requoting that question next time do a search, it's not that hard.
Wyrmie
All titles are based on your prestige. War has nothing to do with it [well unless you gain prestige through war I suppose]. You need to have a title equal to or greater than the one you need to upgrade your palace to a specific level. The level of your palace is the maximum level your other buildings can be upgraded to. Here's a chart:
Knight= 1 prestige [Palace lvl1]
Lord= 3 prestige [Palace lvl2]
Baron= 7 prestige
Viscount= 10 prestige [Palace lvl3]
Count= 15 prestige
Marquis= 20 prestige [Palace lvl4]
Duke= 30 prestige
Prince= 50 prestige [Palace lvl5]
King= 75 prestige
Emperor= 100 prestige

On april 21, 2014
Launcelot

With 10 you'd be alright. But for now there's nothing you can do, the only way to increase population is upgrade granary to level 3 and for that you need to capture 9 villages. Once you do that your max food storage will get a significant boost to 1500. Once you get food to about 1000, give it a few turns and grid will start popping citizens. From where you stand, expect to increase population by 8-9 really fast and by another 3-4 a while later, just make sure granary is maxed out. You probably need a couple more recruiters and traders and spread the rest. No more peasants until population 40, or until you start having trouble keeping stocks full. As a rule of thumb, peasants should be about 50% of population up to level 2 and probably about 40% in level 3. Each level you can decrease their percentage because part of the job is done by the farm, which becomes more efficient after every upgrade.


I used to have a follower buried deep into my kingdom much like yourself and since he had nowhere to go I decided to lend him 9 barbarics just so he could start upgrading to level 3 instead of wasting turns with nothing to do. I got my barbarics back because he wouldn't be able to keep them under control, he became Viscount and by the time I was dead, he had already upgraded his entire capital to level 3 and got population right where he wanted, making his job 100 times easier when he started expanding. Few years later he made Duke.

zen69x The number of one on one fights roughly depends on the number of troops on each side and the wall level. As troops start dying off, the battle slows down. It's normal, attacking capitals or otherwise. You need to plan you battles accordingly.

On may 13, 2014
vrangath

Yeah, your master can


Pass through your territory.


Collect resources.


Collect taxes if you're lands and his are connected or he has passage through lands connecting yours and his.


Attack your lands (but not your capital unless you revolt); but you cannot attack his. Thus if they want to be cruel, they can take your territories and leave you with nothing.


I believe this also prevents you from attacking lands that your master is defending. Thus if they want to help another follower they have, they can simply set a general there defending the other follower's land and you cannot attack it.


They can also defend your lands. They can set a general on your village and set that general to defend. They cannot provoke another players general stationed at your capital, though you can.


Can't think of anything else off the top of my head that a master can do.

is there any way to increase my trading income?

Secondary

On may 18, 2014
NERON

Dump troops into non-capital villages you own, then spend some turns on your grid.


The speed of the increase of income depends on two things:
-Troops; the more troops in the village, the faster the increase
-Income of the village; the farther away the income/loss of the village is from zero, the slower it changes.
On may 18, 2014
zwabberman

okay thanks alot! so i should just keep a few men in the city at all time? or can i use them again after a certain amount of turns without effecting the income?
On may 18, 2014
NERON

As long as the number of troops in the village is more than [income/2-1], you can move them without your trade suffering. However, at [income/2-1], there will be no more trade increase from that specific village until you add more troops.


It's recommended that you put all troops into villages before taking turns on the grid for maximum economy growth.Edit: by income, I mean the income of your specific village, not the net income or trade of your entire kingdom.

NERON

I'm not sure what you're asking but there can be multiple generals and players in one single battle. You can send multiple generals of your own to fight in one battle, which by the way, is a huge waste of resources unless you're bringing reinforcements.


Other players can join existing battles as well, even if they were never part of it to begin with. They just need to send a general, hit 'view battle', then 'join offense/defense'.
On june 16, 2014
[8309421]

Thanks, this was helpful!

And what about the Wall, does it force the general to attack my provinces instead of passing throw them?
On june 16, 2014
NERON

Level one wall prevents people from crossing over your lands. The can go into your village if it's adjacent to land they can cross but to go through they'd need to conquer it first or ask you for passage. This may not seem like much but the fact that one needs to conquer land to reach your capital would deter many opponents, especially distant players in advanced stages of their game because of how the trade system works. It's very important to your defense but I would recommend you build this only after completing all grid multiplier/storage buildings available.


Levels 2-5 reduce the number of individual fights during attacks on your capital by varying degrees. Normally the number of ongoing fights during a battle is determined by the number of units but the wall puts a cap on it, thereby slowing down the battle greatly. It's kind of useless, in my opinion.

On august 2, 2014
DannyMac

There was a meadow which I took 10 horses from. The meadow had 71 horses, however when I took my 10 horses, it only went down to 70. Does it only go down by one each time you harvest it?
On august 2, 2014
NERON

There are two values in the resource zones.


The first value is the amount that you can gather from the zone in total before it depletes. New resources start at 300 units. This is the "71" in your case.


The second value is the amount that you can gather right now from the zone. The cap for this number is 50.


When the second value is less than 50, units from the first value transfer over to the second, slowly.


You likely had a zone with 71/50. You take 10, making it 71/40, then the game starts transferring stored units over 70/41

[8476923]

i want to know that; as soon as i start capturing more villages My trade/gold stars decreasing at a very high rate......... my all gold gets emptied in 6-7 turns and i also looses the control of those villages please help me....
On august 22, 2014
ayalti

Answer has been given on your dedicated topic. But since this is the correct place to ask the question, and the place where future reader might try to read the answer, I repeat it here :
Do not conquer village before having restored positive trade.

When you take a village, its trade contribution is negative, and equal to the square of the distance to your capital. If the village is 5 steps away from your capital, its contribution to your total trade will be -25.
You have to leave troops on it so that, slowly, the trade of the village rise (see posts about trade computation - even if most of them are wrong, they all have a good approximation of the truth)

NERON

You'd need to construct the level 1 Archery for the option to create archers become available. Once that's done, look for troops options under actions to upgrade them from vanilla recruits stationed in your capital.


Further upgrades on the Archery reduces the cost of to upgrade troops. This is the case with all upgraded units and their associated buildings.


Word of warning, archers are a very poor troops and almost always not worth the resources. Advanced players would save the for mounted archers instead.

On august 25, 2014
ayalti

Unless you can't do otherwise (eg soldier are engaged in a battle and you have to take turns (on the grid - because you have 100 turns left), never take turn without all your soldiers in a village (except those you can keep for free in your capital and with generals).

Of course, I can't precisely see what you have (and I am not sure I understood what do you mean by "I have plotted 5-5 soldiers in my captured 5 villages"). But right now, I see that you general Taipan has at least 2 units with him (at least 1 solider, and at least 1 catapult). He has a reputation of 1. So only one of these (at least) two units is for free. The other one cost you money. That is the rule, and there is nothing you can do to avoid that. BUT : you should not take a single turn (unless you can't do otherwise) with that costing solider with your general. This soldier should be in a village, to help your trade rising.

You have probably taken too many villages anyway. But your only chance is to have ALL your soldiers (except the free ones) rise the trade.
And, preferably, all in the village with less trade (in absolute value).
(Of course you have to let in each village the minimum numeber of soldier ; ie no less than 1, and no less than half of your current trade in that village. But all the soldiers over these minimums should be concentrated in the same village : the one with the smallest absolute value of trade = the one where the soldiers will rise the trade most efficiently)

On august 26, 2014
ayalti

Last try :

If you "plot" soldiers in your villages, you will, slowly, rise your TRADE.
It means that it will not be positive at once. But that the derivative is positive. So you will loose less and less at each turn. And at some point your trade will even turn null (you will not loose anything) and even positive (you will earn money at each turn)

But if you have only 100 gold left, it is probably too late.
Your trade will not turn positive before your 100 gold are gone.

Again, your only chance to survive is to try the optimal strategy I've advised. Even if it is too late to avoid all consequence(which mean that you will start loosing people), you can at least minimize the impact of your wrong strategy (taking that much village without ensuring a positive trade before each new conquest)

[6364806]

When viewing the grid, it displays how many turns you have availabe. When you hover your mouse above the number of turns you get a box that says wasted turns. My box says 4/160. What does this mean, is that the number of wasted turns before death?
On august 26, 2014
NERON

Nope. That is the number of wasted turns before the game automatically starts taking "turns" for you. That is to say, nothing happens to your gird but food and gold will be consumed as if turns have been taken. You will also continue aging as if you were taking regular turns.

[8476923]

how many villages should be conquered to become a viscount i.e next level of sir
On august 27, 2014
Launcelot

It's baron first (capital+6), then viscount (capital+9). Also, why don't you conquer the nearest villages first, I see you've already taken a village 3 squares away (now going for another one 2 sq. away) when there is one just next to your capital waiting to be conquered? If you start with the nearest villages first and go all out for trade (dumping troops) then go for the next villages one step at a time, you'll see it's much easier and quicker to expand. Rule of thumb don't skip villages unless the benefit outweighs the cost (like a strategic or a good resource point you need to conquer before the enemy).

On august 28, 2014
Launcelot

About question #2, capital appearance depends only on population size. You start with yellow huts that become brown at about 7-10 citizens. Single tower is at about 25 and you get homes after every few citizens. At about 50 you get a twin tower and then homes like before although you'll notice it's gonna take many more citizens until each one is added. Population cap is -typically- 100 citizens, although it's possible to get as many as 101 or 102 if you're really good at manipulating the grid (and with some luck) and about homes, players don't get the same number, you can peak at 4 homes or 10. In my experience it depends on the capital itself, meaning the same capital will always get the same number (in fact homes pop at exactly the same place too) but every capital is different. Of course like NERON said all that is purely aesthetic so none of that really matters, but it gives you a very good idea of one's population size (which really is a player's strength) so you may avoid getting in over your head.
On august 28, 2014
[8476923]

i got a title baron... i don't no how this will help me.... because i didn't got any upgrades to 3 level...
On august 28, 2014
NERON
NERONAll titles are based on your prestige. You need to have a title equal to or greater than the one you need to upgrade your palace to a specific level. The level of your palace is the maximum level your other buildings can be upgraded to. Here's a chartnight= 1 prestige [Palace lvl1]
Lord= 3 prestige [Palace lvl2]
Baron= 7 prestige
Viscount= 10 prestige [Palace lvl3]
Count= 15 prestige
Marquis= 20 prestige [Palace lvl4]
Duke= 30 prestige
Prince= 50 prestige [Palace lvl5]
King= 75 prestige
Emperor= 100 prestige

EpicBoyMikeThe more soldiers in garrison at a town, the faster trade increases? What's the maximum trade?

That's correct. But the higher it goes the slower it's gonna keep on rising. Maximum trade per village is twice the number of troops minus one i.e. with 10 troops you're good to 19 trade. If you want more you need to add troops. Keep adding troops and trade will be rising indefinitely.

EpicBoyMikeHow many troops should I keep in a village?

for the best trade growth you will approximately have to spread half of your troops amongst all the villages. The other half soul be used for raising the trade in new villages youve recently captured . Example : you control 2000 troops and 40 villages in total . (1000/40) is 25 soldiers in each village . The rest 1000 travels with a general to new location
note that above is only my opinion .

In beginner map Camiliton there are two players (Four Elements and Secret Society) who perform a trick every once in a while. Four Elements is the master of Secret Society. Four Elements is the one with the prestige, while Secret Society has the armies, lots and lots of it.

Every time when Secret Society is at the end of his money, he drop his armies in a province and revolts against his master. His master then suppresses the revolt. Secret Society then takes all his turns with his expensive armies now resting in provinces.

Finally, he picks his armies up and takes a walk once more, conquering new territories for his master.

Rinse and repeat.

I'm not sure if this is legal. What do you say? Should I report this?

Oh, I was just wondering what would happen if you have for example 60 trade, but you only put 15 troops in it, instead of 30. It could potentially be useful for generating extra trade income in fewer turns.
On june 3, 2015
Launcelot

You'll lose the first 10 pretty quick before it slows down, and then it will struggle in the final 10 (40 to 30). If you really have to save some troops, save 5. With the remaining 25 (trade drops to 50) it's gonna take long enough for you to make up for the loss. Generally I don't recommend letting it drop, unless it's by 1 or 2, like 30 troops 61 trade which will take years. Then again, you won't know until you try, but if you're doing it be sure to write the results down.

On june 13, 2015
NERON

Q Is it possible to tell if a person has level 1 wall by simply trying to path your general through from afar, or do you need to be standing in his land and give an order?
On june 13, 2015
[7392589]

Yes, it is possible. Just try to move your general to any of his territories which isn't on his border. If the game lets you do this, your opponent has no wall. When the game doesn't let you do this, your opponent has at least wall lvl 1.
On june 18, 2015
Djisas

On june 24, 2015
Divine

Is it possible to die from bad health taking turns in the middle of an active battle?
On june 25, 2015
NERON

It is possible for your health to degrade (or die if you are in Bad health) every time you spend a turn on the grid under any circumstances
On june 25, 2015
[7392589]

Yes that is possible. Otherwise you could stretch your lifetime forever by saving turns, starting a battle, using your turns, ending the battle.
When you die, your troops will disappear including those that were fighting. The other player will then have won the battle.

On july 1, 2015
Havendes

If I make my trade positive, and then move my troops away, will the trade begin to drop? Also, what is the formula for fixing trade? (How many troops = how much trade)
On july 1, 2015
NERON

The minimum number of troops that need to stay in the village to stabilize is calculated as :
= [Current trade in village] / 2Above that number, your trade will increase, below that number, your trade will fall. In general, the more troops, the faster it increases (or slower it falls). You can find a trade calculator here
